video.title: Advanced OpenGL Tutorial – Skeletal Animations with Assimp
video.description:
In this OpenGL Course, you will take your animation skills to the next level by learning about skeletal animations. This will help your character animations to feel more lifelike when they move thier limbs to do things like walking, running, and attacking.

You will learn how to use the Open Asset Import Library (assimp) to import and export various 3d-model-formats.

✏️ Course created by Etay Meiri. Check out his YouTube channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC7Z1FTCdSln_qFKK95AWplw

⭐️ Course Contents ⭐️
⌨️ (0:00:00) Intro
⌨️ (0:01:29) Loading models using Assimp
⌨️ (0:27:36) Part 1: Rigging, Skinning, and Animating 3D Models
⌨️ (0:48:21) Part 2: Mapping Vertices of Model to Bones
⌨️ (1:03:15) Part 3: Transformation Matrices
⌨️ (1:19:23) Part 4: Integrating Assimp Matrices into Skinned Mesh Class
⌨️ (1:28:06) Part 5: Integrating Animation Data into Skinned Mesh Class

⭐️ Sources ⭐️
💻 Clone the repo at https://github.com/emeiri/ogldev.git. The specific sources are in the following directories:
  💻 Loading models using Assimp: https://github.com/emeiri/ogldev/blob/master/tutorial18_youtube
  💻 Skeletal Animation - Part 1: https://github.com/emeiri/ogldev/blob/master/tutorial24_youtube
  💻 Skeletal Animation - Part 2: https://github.com/emeiri/ogldev/blob/master/tutorial25_youtube
  💻 Skeletal Animation - Part 3: https://github.com/emeiri/ogldev/blob/master/tutorial26_youtube
  💻 Skeletal Animation - Part 4: https://github.com/emeiri/ogldev/blob/master/tutorial27_youtube
  💻 Skeletal Animation - Part 5: https://github.com/emeiri/ogldev/blob/master/tutorial28_youtube

⭐️ Build Instructions ⭐️
Linux - each source directory contains a build.sh and/or build_assimp_sandbox.sh script. Simply run this script from within 
the directory and it will generate a tutorial* executable that matches the index of the tutorial directory. Run the executable 
from the same directory.
Windows - the directory ogldev/Windows/ogldev_vs_2019 contains a Visual Studio 2019 solution file. The relevant projects
are:
Loading models using Assimp: Tutorial18
Skeletal Animation - Part 1: Tutorial24
Skeletal Animation - Part 2: Tutorial25, Tutorial25_assimp_sandbox
Skeletal Animation - Part 3: Tutorial26
Skeletal Animation - Part 4: Tutorial27
Skeletal Animation - Part 5: Tutorial28

⭐️ Credits ⭐️ 
★ Music: https://bensound.com and from the youtube audio library by the artists Huma-Huma and RKVC
★ Image from cleanpng.com by Isbelia
★ Images from pixabay.com by VOLLEX, Gordon Johnson, OpenClipart-Vectors
★ Video from pixabay.com by Timo Herbert

🎉 Thanks to our Champion and Sponsor supporters:
👾 Raymond Odero
👾 Agustín Kussrow
👾 aldo ferretti
👾 Otis Morgan
👾 DeezMaster

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://freecodecamp.org/news

topLevelComment.author: Limes border line - indie game
topLevelComment.text:
Thank you very much for your work.
I watch your ogldev tutorial all the time. Bone import from Blender is garbled. How to fix the offset matrix?

replies.author: Limes border line - indie game
replies.text: @OGLDEV Yes it is possible.

replies.author: OGLDEV
replies.text: @Limes border line - indie game Cool, so if you have some code to share please do.

replies.author: Limes border line - indie game
replies.text: ​@OGLDEV Yes, that's exactly what I meant. I did it a little differently. I paid a lot of attention to metadata. I realized that I only need to take node transformation matrices. I started to understand the code. Thanks.

replies.author: OGLDEV
replies.text: @Limes border line - indie game Not sure if I understood. Are you saying that the problem should be solved in the code and not in the way the export from Blender takes place?

replies.author: Limes border line - indie game
replies.text: @OGLDEV Blender does not write data to metadata. But Blender writes a transformation matrix to each node. The matrix is passed to the node's parent. This matrix should be used universally. Multiplication by the global matrix. The same is true when calculating the mBones[i]->mOffsetMatrix matrix. For each node of the matrix, the transformations are the same. It can be viewed through the asimp viewer. Can this solution. Since FBX Review correctly reads such a file. You don’t even need to adjust the axes in Blender.

topLevelComment.author: 3D
topLevelComment.text: why not Vulkan still OpenGL

replies.author: OGLDEV
replies.text: @3D Right. I think the main challenge in Vulkan is that you need to replace the work of the driver in so many ways. The benefit of course is performance. So the target audience is people who already have experience in 3D and are willing to put in the effort in order to gain an increase in performance.

replies.author: 3D
replies.text: @OGLDEV yeah, and they can learn GLSL, also used in Vulkan

replies.author: OGLDEV
replies.text: I hope to do a series on Vulkan as well but it requires significant effort and I still haven't found the time for it. However, programming in Vulkan is much more difficult and even people who want to develop game engines should probably get their hands dirty with a simpler API first.

topLevelComment.author: Danny Michelle
topLevelComment.text: OpenGL is kinda outdated. I only see it in education now

replies.author: OGLDEV
replies.text: As noted below, Vulkan is the next gen API after OpenGL, however, it is very complex and targets people who develop game engines or high end applications that require top performance. Many people will continue using OpenGL for a long time. Regarding your comment - it depends on the OS. On Windows DirectX is the first choice but on Android you have to use OpenGL-ES which is a slim down version of OpenGL. DirectX is also not available on Linux. I actually started with OpenGL because I wanted to do 3D graphics on Linux which is my favorite environment. I think that the consoles are also using APIs that are more or less similar to OpenGL.

replies.author: OGLDEV
replies.text: @Hannan Zubair OpenGL has been deprecated by Apple so it still kind of works on old platforms for backward compatibility of existing applications. You need to switch to Metal.

replies.author: Hannan Zubair
replies.text: openGL doesn't work on macbooks. Do you know if there is an alternative?

replies.author: astroid 5698
replies.text: @Puranjan Prithu Vulkan, But there are also other good intermediate middleware rendering abstraction layers such as BGFX and WGPU, It is much preferable to use those than to translate the rendering code for each platform that exists out there (Vulkan, Metal, DirectX, OpenGL, etc..)
